title: Use of Pupil Area and Fixation Maps to Evaluate Visual Behavior of Drivers inside Tunnels at Different Luminance Levels—A Pilot Study
summary: This study investigates the visual behavior of drivers in tunnels under different luminance levels, using pupil area and fixation maps to evaluate their gaze patterns. The research focuses on improving traffic safety in tunnels by understanding how drivers' visual features change with illumination.
methodology: The study used non-intrusive eye-tracking equipment to collect data from six experienced drivers in a relatively long tunnel during the daytime, at three luminance levels (2 cd/m2, 2.5 cd/m2, and 3 cd/m2).
research_outcomes: The results demonstrated that luminance levels had a significant effect on pupil areas and fixation zones. Fixation area and average pupil area had a significant negative correlation with luminance levels during the daytime.

title: Medications, Deep Brain Stimulation, and Other Factors Influencing Impulse Control Disorders in Parkinson's Disease
summary: This review paper examines the factors influencing impulse control disorders (ICDs) in patients with Parkinson's disease. The authors discuss various risk factors, including demographics, medical and surgical associations, premorbidities and comorbidities, family history and genetics, and personality traits. They conclude that dopamine alone cannot account for all ICDs and highlight the need for further investigation.
methodology: The authors use a review methodology to summarize the known risk factors and associations with ICDs in PD patients.
research_outcomes: The study highlights the complexity of ICDs in PD patients and the need for further investigation into their etiology and management.

title: Polymer Optical Fiber Sensors in Healthcare Applications: A Comprehensive Review
summary: This paper presents a comprehensive review of polymer optical fiber sensors in healthcare applications, discussing their advantages and potential for widespread use. The authors highlight the benefits of POF sensors in various healthcare devices, including movement analysis, physiological parameters monitoring, and instrumentation of robotic devices.
methodology: The paper presents a literature review of existing research on polymer optical fiber sensors in healthcare applications.
research_outcomes: The authors conclude that POF sensors have the potential to revolutionize healthcare by providing accurate and reliable measurements, improving patient outcomes, and reducing healthcare costs.

title: Interpretable machine learning-derived nomogram model for early detection of diabetic retinopathy in type 2 diabetes mellitus: a widely targeted metabolomics study
summary: This paper proposes an interpretable machine learning-derived nomogram model for early detection of diabetic retinopathy in type 2 diabetes mellitus using metabolomics and clinical indicators. The model shows excellent performance in predicting DR, with AUCs of 0.99 (95% CI) in both training and testing sets.
methodology: Propensity score matching-based case-control study using metabolomics techniques and machine learning algorithms
statistics: Hosmer–Lemeshow test, receiver operating characteristic curve, decision curve analysis
research_outcomes: The nomogram model shows excellent quality of classification for DR detection, with a reasonable degree of calibration.

title: A novel stroke risk model using machine learning techniques
summary: This paper presents a new stroke risk model developed using machine learning techniques, specifically extreme gradient boosting (XGBoost), to predict 1-year thromboembolic events in Chinese patients with atrial fibrillation. The model integrates three key variables: congestive heart failure or left ventricular dysfunction, age, and prior stroke, and outperforms the widely-used CHA2DS2-VA score in predicting low-risk patients.
methodology: The study used a prospective cohort design, with data collected from the China Atrial Fibrillation Registry. The XGBoost algorithm was used to select important features and construct a Cox proportional hazards model. The risk score was derived from coefficients of the three variables in the Cox regression model.
research_outcomes: The novel stroke risk model (CAS) outperformed the CHA2DS2-VA score in predicting low-risk patients and had a higher C-statistic. The CAS model identified a large proportion of patients with low risk of TEs, which could potentially improve anticoagulation decision-making.

title: Effectiveness and treatment moderators of internet interventions for adult problem drinking: An individual patient data meta-analysis of 19 randomised controlled trials
summary: This paper investigates the effectiveness and moderators of treatment outcomes in internet-based interventions for adult problem drinking. The study conducted a one-stage individual patient data meta-analysis (IPDMA) on 19 randomised controlled trials, including 14,198 adults at baseline. The results show that internet-based alcohol interventions are effective in reducing mean weekly alcohol consumption and achieving adherence to low-risk drinking limits, but the use of waitlist control may inflate outcomes.
methodology: The study used a systematic search approach to identify relevant trials, followed by a one-stage individual patient data meta-analysis (IPDMA) using linear mixed models. The primary outcome measure was mean weekly alcohol consumption in standard units (SUs), and secondary outcomes included treatment response (TR).
statistics: linear mixed models, odds ratio (OR), number needed to treat (NNT)
research_outcomes: The study found that internet-based interventions are effective in reducing mean weekly alcohol consumption and achieving adherence to low-risk drinking limits. Human-guided interventions showed a stronger impact on treatment outcome than fully automated ones.

title: Feasibility and acceptability of a milk and resistance exercise intervention to improve muscle function in community-dwelling older adults (MIlkMAN): Pilot study
summary: This pilot study examines the feasibility and acceptability of a milk and resistance exercise intervention to improve muscle function in community-dwelling older adults. The study found that the intervention was feasible and acceptable, but did not show significant improvements in muscle strength or function.
methodology: The study used a parallel groups design with three arms: whole milk + resistance exercise, skimmed milk + resistance exercise, and control drink + resistance exercise. Participants performed a 6-week community-based resistance exercise programme and consumed either whole milk, skimmed milk, or an isocaloric carbohydrate drink after each exercise session.
research_outcomes: The study found that the intervention was feasible and acceptable, with high recruitment and attendance rates. However, there were no significant improvements in muscle strength or function compared to the control group.

title: Effect of N-acetylcysteine on remission maintenance in patients with ulcerative colitis: A Randomized controlled clinical trial
summary: This study investigates the effect of N-acetylcysteine on remission maintenance in patients with ulcerative colitis. The research focuses on the antioxidant properties of NAC and its potential to prevent relapse in UC patients, but does not involve any machine learning or artificial intelligence methods.
methodology: The study employed a randomized controlled clinical trial design, where patients were randomly assigned to receive either NAC supplementation or placebo. The primary outcome was remission maintenance, and secondary outcomes included endoscopic relapse, serum levels of hs-CRP, hemoglobin, and fecal calprotectin.
statistics: Statistical analysis was performed using SPSS version 21, including chi-square test, independent t-test, one-way analysis of covariance (ANCOVA), Kaplan-Meier methodology, and log-rank test.
research_outcomes: The study found that NAC supplementation significantly improved remission maintenance compared to placebo. Patients in the NAC group had a lower rate of relapse and better endoscopic outcomes.

title: Deep Learning-Based Postoperative Recovery and Nursing of Total Hip Arthroplasty
summary: This paper presents a deep learning-assisted recovery and nursing system for total hip arthroplasty, utilizing Mask R-CNN to improve postoperative care. The model is trained on human hip X-ray images and can accurately identify prosthetic structures, predict complications, and assist doctors in formulating postoperative care plans.
methodology: The study uses a deep learning-based approach, specifically Mask R-CNN, to analyze X-ray images of patients with hip lesions. The model is trained on manually labeled medical images and can accurately identify prosthetic structures, predict complications, and assist doctors in formulating postoperative care plans.
statistics: Statistical methods used: VAS index, Harris score, Barthel index
research_outcomes: The study found that the application of deep learning method in rapid nursing after total hip replacement can significantly improve the nursing ability. The model was able to accurately identify prosthetic structures, predict complications, and assist doctors in formulating postoperative care plans.

title: Exploring Sentiment and Care Management of Hospitalized Patients During the First Wave of the COVID-19 Pandemic Using Electronic Nursing Health Records: Descriptive Study
summary: This study explores the use of electronic nursing health records to analyze sentiment and care management of hospitalized patients during the COVID-19 pandemic. The authors used a descriptive study design, analyzing the textual content of electronic nursing clinical notes (ENCN) from nurses working in post-intensive care units for COVID-19 and non-COVID-19 wards. Sentiment analysis was performed using the National Research Council of Canada's Emotion Lexicon, Affin, and Bing dictionaries, revealing significant differences in sentiment between patients with COVID-19 and those without.
methodology: The study used a descriptive study design, analyzing the textual content of ENCN from nurses working in post-intensive care units for COVID-19 and non-COVID-19 wards. Sentiment analysis was performed using the National Research Council of Canada's Emotion Lexicon, Affin, and Bing dictionaries.
statistics: Statistical analysis was performed using the R package (version 3.5.1). The level of significance was established at P<.05.
research_outcomes: The study found significant differences in sentiment between patients with COVID-19 and those without. The authors concluded that electronic nursing health records can be used to analyze sentiment and care management of hospitalized patients during the COVID-19 pandemic.

title: Children’s Rare Disease Cohorts: An Integrative Research and Clinical Genomics Initiative
summary: This paper presents the Children's Rare Disease Cohorts initiative, a program at Boston Children's Hospital integrating genomic, research, and clinical data to expedite pediatric precision medicine. The authors developed a genomics learning system (GLS) for storage and use of the data, which was used to analyze clinical and research data of an additional set of 6075 exomes and 112 genomes.
methodology: The authors developed a genomics learning system (GLS) for storage and use of the data, which integrated analytical systems, including machine learning algorithms for automated variant classification and prioritization, as well as phenotype extraction via NLP of clinical notes.
research_outcomes: The CRDC initiative enrolled 2441 participants and collected genotypic data and phenotypic data from the medical record and research surveys. The GLS was used to analyze clinical and research data, resulting in improved gene discovery and diagnosis rates.
sources_of_inspiration: National Institutes of Health's Genomic Data Sharing Policy
Global Alliance for Genomics and Health (GA4GH) Data Use Ontology

title: A practical guide to preclinical systematic review and meta-analysis
summary: This paper provides a comprehensive guide to conducting preclinical systematic reviews (SRs) and meta-analyses (MAs), highlighting their importance in generating empirical evidence for robust experimental design, informing research strategy, and supporting funding applications. The authors emphasize that SRs can be conducted without machine learning expertise, using free and widely accessible software.
methodology: The paper outlines the methodology for conducting preclinical SRs, including identifying, selecting, and critically appraising available literature to answer a specific research question in an unbiased manner.
research_outcomes: Preclinical SRs provide empirical evidence to improve study design, methods, and analysis, increasing usability, accessibility, and reproducibility. They can also inform clinical trial design and establish whether there is evidence to justify a clinical trial.

title: Differentiation of Cytomegalovirus and Herpes Simplex Virus Esophagitis Based on Endoscopic Findings
summary: This paper investigates the differentiation of cytomegalovirus (CMV) and herpes simplex virus (HSV) esophagitis based on endoscopic findings. The authors develop a predictive model to distinguish between the two conditions, which is challenging due to overlapping endoscopic features. The study uses logistic regression analysis and receiver operating characteristic (ROC) curve analysis to evaluate the model's performance.
methodology: The study used a retrospective cohort design, analyzing data from 169 patients with suspected CMV or HSV esophagitis. Endoscopic findings were categorized into four categories using average linkage clustering, and logistic regression analysis was used to identify candidate variables for differentiating CMV esophagitis from HSV esophagitis.
statistics: chi-square test, Fisher exact test, Student's t test, Mann-Whitney U test
research_outcomes: The authors developed a predictive model with good discriminatory power (area under the ROC curve = 0.967) to differentiate between CMV and HSV esophagitis based on endoscopic findings.

title: Diabetic Retinopathy Detection by Image Processing Algorithms and Machine Learning Technique
summary: This paper presents a machine learning-based approach for detecting diabetic retinopathy from fundus images. The proposed system uses Support Vector Machine (SVM) classification and image processing techniques to identify microaneurysms, hemorrhages, and exudates in the retina. The method is shown to be effective in distinguishing between normal eyes, diabetic retinopathy, and Age-related Macular Degeneration (AMD).
methodology: The proposed system uses a combination of image processing techniques, including adaptive histogram equalization, median filtering, and edge zero padding, to preprocess the fundus images. The preprocessed images are then fed into an SVM classifier for classification.
research_outcomes: The proposed system is shown to achieve high accuracy in detecting diabetic retinopathy from fundus images.

title: Toward improved endoscopic examination of urinary stones: a concordance study between endoscopic digital pictures vs microscopy
summary: This paper presents a concordance study between endoscopic and microscopic observations of urinary stones. The authors aim to improve the recognition of urinary stone morphologies using endoscopic examination, which is essential in lithiasis. However, machine learning or artificial intelligence methods are not used in this study.
methodology: The study adhered to all local regulations and data protection agency recommendations. An expert urologist intraoperatively and prospectively examined stones using a flexible digital ureterorenoscope. Visual cues were considered for the estimation of stone type, and laser-based stone section was performed.
research_outcomes: The study demonstrates the feasibility of using endoscopic morphology for urinary stones recognition. The overall matching rate was 81.6%. Diagnostics were confirmed for specific morphologies, and didactic boards of confirmed endoscopic images are provided.

title: DeepAISE -- An End-to-End Development and Deployment of a Recurrent Neural Survival Model for Early Prediction of Sepsis
summary: This paper presents DeepAISE, a recurrent neural survival model for early prediction of sepsis. The model uses clinical criteria and treatment policies to rank the relative utility of various consensus criteria through policy evaluation. The authors show that by coupling a criterion with a treatment policy, one can use the framework of Attributable Treatment Effect Estimates (ATEE) to compare the different criteria.
methodology: The methodology involves using a recurrent neural network to predict sepsis onset time based on clinical risk factors and temporal patterns. The model is trained on two cohorts: Emory and MIMIC-III.
statistics: Survival analysis, attributable treatment effect-size estimates
research_outcomes: The study shows that the Third International Consensus Definition of Sepsis (Sepsis-3) criterion is more effective than the Center for Disease Control (CDC) criterion in predicting sepsis onset time. The authors also demonstrate the use of ATEE to compare different treatment policies and identify the most optimal one.
sources_of_inspiration: Third International Consensus Definitions for Sepsis

title: Effects of high-intensity interval and moderate-intensity continuous aerobic exercise on diabetic obese patients with nonalcoholic fatty liver disease
summary: This study investigates the effects of high-intensity interval and moderate-intensity continuous aerobic exercise on diabetic obese patients with nonalcoholic fatty liver disease. The research finds that both types of exercise reduce hepatic fat and visceral lipids, but there is no significant difference between the two groups.
methodology: Randomized controlled trial
statistics: Analysis of variance, paired t test
research_outcomes: Both high-intensity interval and moderate-intensity continuous aerobic exercise reduce hepatic fat and visceral lipids in diabetic obese patients with nonalcoholic fatty liver disease.

title: Long non-coding RNA profile study identifies a metabolism-related signature for colorectal cancer
summary: This paper presents a novel approach to predicting outcomes of colorectal cancer patients by identifying a metabolism-related long non-coding RNA signature. The study uses machine learning techniques to integrate clinical data and transcriptome information, resulting in a prognostic scoring system that can predict patient prognosis with high accuracy.
methodology: The study used a combination of machine learning algorithms and statistical methods to identify metabolism-related long non-coding RNAs associated with colorectal cancer outcomes. The methodology involved data preprocessing, feature selection, model training, and validation using external cohorts.
statistics: Pearson test, Wilcoxon test, Kruskal-Wallis test, univariate cox proportional hazards regression
research_outcomes: The study identified a metabolism-related long non-coding RNA signature that can predict patient prognosis with high accuracy. The nomogram constructed using the risk score and clinical parameters showed good predictive ability.

title: FLAIRectomy: Resecting beyond the Contrast Margin for Glioblastoma
summary: This paper discusses the resection of peri-tumoral FLAIR signal in glioblastoma patients, which has been shown to improve survival outcomes. The authors review existing studies on the composition of peri-tumoral FLAIR and its relationship with patient survival, highlighting the importance of considering FLAIRectomy as a treatment option for GBM.
methodology: The paper reviews existing literature on the topic, using histopathological and imaging studies to understand the role of FLAIR signal in glioblastoma progression and recurrence.
research_outcomes: The study finds that resection of peri-tumoral FLAIR signal is associated with improved survival outcomes in GBM patients. The authors suggest that FLAIRectomy may be a valuable treatment option for improving patient outcomes.

title: Identification and Analysis of Glioblastoma Biomarkers Based on Single Cell Sequencing
summary: This paper identifies biomarkers for glioblastoma tumors using single-cell RNA sequencing and computational methods. The study applies machine learning algorithms, specifically support vector machines, to screen core biomarkers that can distinguish between tumor cells and surrounding tissue. The results provide insights into GBM mechanisms and may be useful for diagnosis and therapy.
methodology: The study uses single-cell RNA sequencing data from Gene Expression Omnibus (GEO) to analyze the gene expression profiles of glioblastoma tumor cells and surrounding tissue. The maximum relevance minimum redundancy (mRMR) method is used to select core biomarkers, and support vector machines are applied for classification.
research_outcomes: 31 important genes were extracted as potential biomarkers for GBM tumor cells. An optimal classification model using a support vector machine algorithm was also built.

title: The Impact of Mind-Body Exercises on Motor Function, Depressive Symptoms, and Quality of Life in Parkinson’s Disease: A Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis
summary: This systematic review and meta-analysis investigates the effects of mind-body exercises (Tai Chi, Yoga, Health Qigong) on motor function, depressive symptoms, and quality of life in patients with Parkinson’s disease. The study finds significant improvements in motor function, depressive symptoms, and quality of life, suggesting that mind-body exercises can be an effective method for clinical exercise intervention in PD patients.
methodology: Systematic review and meta-analysis
statistics: Meta-analysis using Cochrane collaboration software (Review Manager 5.3) and Stata14.0
research_outcomes: Significant improvements in motor function, depressive symptoms, and quality of life in patients with Parkinson’s disease

title: Real-time Surgical Tools Recognition in Total Knee Arthroplasty Using Deep Neural Networks
summary: This paper proposes a real-time surgical tools recognition system for total knee arthroplasty using deep neural networks. The system uses a convolutional neural network (CNN) to detect surgical tools in real-time, improving the accuracy and precision of TKA procedures.
methodology: The proposed method uses a region-based convolutional neural network (R-CNN) architecture, which includes a base network with 16 convolutional layers and a region proposal network (RPN).
research_outcomes: The system achieved 87.6% mAP, outperforming state-of-the-art methods for tools detection.

title: Advance Care Planning and Care Coordination for People With Parkinson's Disease and Their Family Caregivers—Study Protocol for a Multicentre, Randomized Controlled Trial
summary: This study evaluates the impact and feasibility of a nurse-led palliative care intervention for people with Parkinson's disease across seven European countries. The intervention focuses on Advance Care Planning (ACP) and care coordination, aiming to improve quality of life and manage end-of-life perspectives.
methodology: Multicentre, single-blinded randomized controlled parallel group design
statistics: Mantel–Haenszel methods and multilevel logistic regression models
research_outcomes: Effectiveness of a nurse-led palliative care intervention for people with PD and their family caregivers; feasibility of the PD_Pal intervention across seven European countries

title: Effects of the sodium–glucose co-transporter 2 inhibitor dapagliflozin in patients with type 2 diabetes and Stages 3b–4 chronic kidney disease
summary: This paper investigates the effects of dapagliflozin, a sodium-glucose co-transporter 2 inhibitor, in patients with type 2 diabetes and Stages 3b–4 chronic kidney disease. The study found that dapagliflozin did not decrease HbA1c levels but decreased UACR, BP, and body weight to a clinically meaningful extent.
methodology: The study used a pooled analysis of 11 phase 3 randomized controlled clinical trials to examine the effects of dapagliflozin in patients with type 2 diabetes and Stages 3b–4 CKD.
statistics: Descriptive statistics were used for presenting baseline characteristics and safety data. The mean change from baseline value and 95% confidence interval (CI) were derived using a longitudinal repeated measures mixed model.
research_outcomes: The study found that dapagliflozin decreased UACR, BP, and body weight but did not decrease HbA1c levels in patients with type 2 diabetes and Stages 3b–4 CKD.

title: Evaluation of Adherence to Anti-Retroviral Treatment: Experience of SANRU, DRC
summary: This study evaluates adherence to anti-retroviral treatment (ART) in the Democratic Republic of Congo. The authors analyzed data from 2586 patients and found that 82% were adherent to ART, with a strong association between adherence and the presence of HIV care trained healthcare providers.
methodology: Cross-sectional study using SPSS software package 21.0 version for data analysis
research_outcomes: The study found that adherence to ART was strongly associated with the presence of HIV care trained healthcare providers and setting/distance between facilities and patient's habitat.
